reviewText: When people say that 'The Simpsons Movie' was one of the most anticipated film releases of this past summer, I often think to myself that perhaps "one of the most anticipated film releases of the past 18 years" would be more applicable.'The Simpsons' is, of course, American television's longest running sitcom, and is now entering its 19th season.  Though each season has been great in my opinion, the idea of a Big Screen debut for The Simpsons was always a lingering, tantilizing possibility.  With the release of the 'South Park' movie a few years back, as well as an extended episode of Fox's other "family" cartoon show released on DVD, Simpsons fans' appetites were further whetted.Then came the news that all Simpsons fans were yearning to hear, from long term fans (like myself) to new fans of the series: 'The Simpsons Movie' would finally be made, scheduled for a Summer 2007 release.  Of course, then came the anxiety of waiting for its release, all the while wondering whether it would be a flop or "the" movie we'd been waiting for.  After seeing it on the night of its release and here, only a few shorts months until its DVD release, it is safe to say that it is the latter.'The Simpsons Movie' lives up to its hype; it is the result of endless hours of brainstorming by many of the show's writers, both current and old.  It includes in-jokes and returning characters that long term fans will appreciate while implemeting a fluid and consistent story line throughout.  The jokes within are some of the series' finest, and yet it does not feel like an extended episode, a common concern shared by many.  Overall, it is a fantastic creation by the many genius minds behind this genius series.Fans of this show that have yet to see this film, rest assured, it does not disappoint.  To close, the rumored DVD Special Features list is vast, including several deleted scenes, interviews, TV spots, and more.  For $15.99, this is simply a must-have DVD released just in time for the holidays.

reviewText: I have loved watching The Simpsons for years, but I cannot express how disappointed I was by this movie.  Everyone I asked about it who saw it before I did, and nearly every review I read, was so kind to it and told me how great it was, and I now have to wonder if every single one of them was lying.Because I feel lied to.This movie is, at best, like a moderately funny episode of the show.  In no way does it equal even one of the best episodes, or justify at all its more-than-$60-million-dollar budget.  It structure is uneven and choppy, its jokes are too few, and at times it even blatantly rehashes jokes and scenes from the show without altering them at all.The film is loaded with the cheesiest and most forced sorts of Simpson-esque jokes; the kind that usually only appears about once every episode is absolutely rampant here.  The beginning (set in a movie theater) doesn't flow into the scenes that follow, and the scenes at the very end jump back in time to before the movie's climax.  The jokes could be so much funnier, the story could be smoother, the satire could have been much less heavy-handed, and that much-lauded "Spider-Pig" song would be a lot funnier if it was only used once and not brought out over and over.The movie was just so disappointing to me, and to a lot of discerning Simpsons fans I know, in part because I really thought it could have been great.  Instead, it was so much less than great--just okay--disappointing enough that I haven't really wanted to watch the show much since seeing this.
summary: A kick in the crotch for loyal fans

reviewText: Springfield will never be the same when Homer J. Simpson (Dan Castellaneta) dumps a silo of pig crap into the rivers, rather than drop it off at the recycling plant, so he could get free donuts. His mistake haunts him as the quaint town is covered by a dome under orders of EPA leader Russ Cargill (Albert Brooks), and the townspeople rightfully put the blame on Homer. Eventually, he and his family - Marge (Julie Kavner), Bart (Nancy Cartwright), Lisa (Yeardley Smith), and Maggie (Nancy Cartwright) - escape from their wrath and take residence in Alaska. Things aren't too problematic until president Arnold Schwarzenegger (Harry Shearer) is mistakenly fooled by Cargill into blowing up Springfield to make room for a monumental canyon gap. Now it's up to the Simpsons, especially the disgraced Homer, to get back on the town's good graces by saving the day.If there's any hit TV show that never hit the big screen yet, it's the classic animated sitcom "The Simpsons". Even before "South Park" and "Family Guy", the classic cartoon from writers Matt Groening and James L. Brooks (director of any film starring Albert Brooks or Jack Nicholson) was the originator of biting satire, political commentary, and plain old sitcom hijinks that we've come to love (bratty boys, insecure girls, fat husbands, neurotic wives, crazy Christians, botox-addicted news announcers, raspy-voiced sisters, stoner bus drivers, hardened educators, etc.). And where do we go from there? The silver screen, that's where.Directed by series producer David Silverman, and written by nearly everyone from the show, "The Simpsons Movie" doesn't really need to expand upon their formula, considering that they've pretty much done it all (hence a familiar quote from "South Park": "Simpsons did it."). Following a flat-out hilarious "Itchy & Scratchy" short that's basically a classic Disney short with twisted slapstick, we're given a very familiar opening of the show that highlights all of the main characters of the show, concluding with a memorable performance by punk rock legends Green Day. Stuff like that is a sign for "Simpsons" die hard fans that they're definitely gonna have yet another good time, and I can't lie there.Of course, that doesn't mean it's another walk in the park with a PG-13 rating. Bart's nudity often covered in "Austin Powers"-type fashion? Marge taking the Lord's name in vain? Otto enjoying his last toke session at Doomsday? Sure, it ain't much, but the comic timing of the material is what makes it all work, especially any other gags.It was wise for the entire cast to join in on the proceedings, and everyone gives sharp line readings. Homer is front and center of this picture, the lazy dad character with such likeability and charm for us to follow with him, and no other talented voice actor like Dan Castellaneta (who juggles other roles including town drunk Barney, Donald Trump surrogate Mayor Quimby, kids TV show duo Krusty the Clown and Sideshow Mel, and various others) could give the character whatever personality it calls for. Also joining Castellaneta with equal comic timing are Hank Azaria (Doctor Nick, Drederick Tatum, Apu, Bumblebee Man, Carl, Cletus, Chief Wiggum, Comic Book Guy, Moe, Lou, Professor Frink, Sea Captain), Nancy Cartwright (Bart Simpson, Maggie Simpson, Nelson, Ralph, Todd Flanders), Julie Kavner (Marge Simpson), Harry Shearer (Arnold Schwarzenegger, Dr. Hibbert, Kent Brockman, Lenny, Montgomery Burns, Ned Flanders, Otto, Principal Seymour Skinner, Skull, Smithers), Yeardley Smith (Lisa Simpson), and so much more that could fill nearly 1,000 pages. There's also cameos from the likes of Green Day, Albert Brooks, Tom Hanks (as himself, promoting a new gap in Springfield and poking fun at his high-popular image - seeing him in his first comedic role in three years is a welcome respite from "The Da Vinci Code" and such), and many more.The Simpsons isn't necessarily a long movie (it's about 85 minutes). But there's plenty of material that the audience will crave. Whether it's the satire (Ah-nold as president, which is as funny as it sounds), the in-jokes (below the screen in one scene, there's a marquee that highlights upcoming shows on the FOX network, there's a "To Be Continued...Immediately sign), or the colorful composition of Hans Zimmer (who brings his experience of action and comedy scores to the fray, as well as a great re-iteration of the Simpsons theme song), there's plenty of goodies to engorge yourself into if you either love the TV show, or have become a fresh newcomer. Not since "Surf's Up" have I enjoyed such a well-written and hilarious animated film this summer.

reviewText: I saw this movie in the summer of 2007 when it first came out. Like many, I found it amusing but because of the anticipation and the hype it seemed a little flat.  Recently, I acquired a copy of the DVD and my impression changed dramatically when seeing it again, at home.  This is a great movie.The Simpsons TV show has always satirized the heartwarming family saga that is the mainstay of American television while paradoxically being the best heartwarming American family saga on TV. The longer length of the movie allows for bigger and better satiric riffs on contemporary culture.There's some great stuff here: Bart's skateboard ride, spiderpig and the send-up of the Disney animated features as Marge and Homer get ready for bed in the Alaskan cabin.The commentary by the creators about the need for balancing Homer's character throws an insightful look at the creative process in general and gives hint at why this movie took so long to make.  Much of the humor stems from Homer's comic failings which mirror the worst in American culture: he's obese, lazy and self-centered.  The commentary on making him bad enough to be funny but not so bad as to lose the audience's sympathy is one of the best of the special features on the DVD.

reviewText: After nearly 20 years of being America's first animated family, The Simpsons come to the big screen in their highly anticipated feature film debut, and not only has it been worth the wait, but those who have been in fear of the film's quality (because let's face it, the show isn't nearly as funny as it used to be) will be pleasently surprised by how The Simpsons Movie turns out.  As the ultra polluted lake in Springfield grows ever worse (with Homer topping it off, naturally), the Environmental Protection Agency (epa!!! epa!!! epa!!!) quarintines Springfield, cutting everyone off from the outside world.  Of course, it's up to Homer, Marge, Lisa, Bart, and even baby Maggie to save the day, and their home town.  There isn't necessarily anything original about The Simpsons Movie, but the laughs come much quicker than you anticipate them to, along with some just plain laugh out loud moments of hysteria (Bart's nude skateboarding trip in particular comes to mind), and in that department alone, The Simpsons Movie succeeds mightily.  The animation has been touched up for the big screen, and while the movie doesn't always take advantage of not being restrained by the restrictions of prime time network television, make no mistake that The Simpsons Movie is the best comedy you'll see this summer, and very well maybe all year long.  All in all, The Simpsons Movie is much better than I had anticipated it to be, and fans who may have feared the quality of the film adaptation should feel waves of relief upon them.

reviewText: The "Simpsons" have been around coming on two decades now, becoming so evolved an episode of second- or third-tier characters are as interesting as ones involving the actual family. I remember hearing stories about the upcoming Simpsons movie from when the show first debuted.Well, the Simpsons movie is here, but for better or worse, it's just a very long, average quality episode. (The South Park movie was an exception.)The movie begins on the perfect note: Homer criticized the audience for seeing something at the movies that they could have seen at home for free. Several threads emerge: Grandpa goes into a religious trance at church and prophecizes doom, Bart streaks through Springfield and becomes a third son for Ned Flanders, Lisa sparks a cleanup of Lake Springfield after it consumes Green Day, and Homer adopts a pig.Homer then dumps a silo filled with the pig's manure into the lake, triggering an environmental disaster. The EPA then drops a dome over the city, sealing it from the world. The Simpsons escape and embark on a trip of Alaska, but return once Springfield is threatened with destruction.The film entertains like the Simpsons we know and love, but absolutely nothing distinguishes the movie from what could have been a multi-part episode. reviewText: First things first: The Simpsons Movie is nothing more than a longer version of the show.  But is that really a bad thing, provided it's a quality longer version of the show?  Truth be told, this is quality stuff, and while it doesn't break any new ground, it milks the Simpsons name for what its worth and also harks back to some of the Simpsons golden days.Besides being a gag-ridden tour de force complete with a the now infamous spiderpig song, the story has elements from some of best of the earliest Simpsons moments.  Specifically, the film focuses highly on the family's relationships, something that was done to a tee til roughly about season 10 or 11.  Since then it's been a slew of gags (mostly funny ones though).  The story involves the Simpsons getting kicked out of Springfield because Homer has been resposible for over polluting the city.  It is pretty basic, but it allows for, believe it or not, focus on Marge and the kids trying to rectify their relationship with Homer.  It's done pretty well and reminds me of some of those earliest episodes.But besides the story, oh is it funny!  There is self deprecating humor (why would anyone pay to see something they could see on TV for free).  There is a number of jabs at the government and a hilarious cameo by a certain two time academy award winner.There have been a few people who have griped about the extras, but that's to be expected from die hard fans.  There are two commentaries and are just as entertaining and informative as the commentaries that have accompanied the series box sets.  And remember those trailers we saw in theaters before the movie was released?  Those are here (I like the bunny ones).  There are some mildly amusing deleted scenes and a couple other goodies.So will the Simpsons movie be put on a pedestal of great cinema?  Probably not.  It's probably the best thing the Simpsons have had in awhile.  Also, like any good Simpsons episode, it allows for repeated viewings and there's numerous little in jokes to catch when you go back.  And now, you can take Spiderpig home to play over and over again...

reviewText: It's tough to review a film like this, because it is for such a particular audience.  If you know and love the Simpsons...you simply MUST go.  If you've never seen the Simpsons, you probably wouldn't go to the movie anyway...but if you did, you'd certainly miss out on most of the fun.  The movie TOTALLY assumes you already know all the people...there's no introduction, no easing into it.  It's basically like 4 great episodes strung together.But that's too simple.  To me, the makers of the film had to overcome the obstacle of how to bring an 18 year old series to the screen and make it seem worthwhile...not just charging money to see something that we could see at home.  So how did they succeed so well?To me, many, many episodes of the Simpsons revolve around Homer screwing up something so bad that he's seriously in the dog-house with Marge, and must then try to win back her affections.  Well, in the movie, Homer mananges his BIGGEST screw-up ever and it results in much, much more than simply ticking Marge off.  Their marriage is truly threatened.  When that moment sinks in for the two of them...it's touching filmmaking indeed.  When did a couple of hapless cartoon characters become capable of bringing us to tears?  (Years and years ago, actually...but the film drives it home).Also, the animation is kicked up a notch...mostly because the backgrounds are much richer than the TV show.  It's the Springfield we know...but it's also more textured.  And there are a couple of scenes so monstrously huge (I don't want to spoil anything, but they involved Homer on a motorcycle inside a giant glass dome) that they BEG to be enjoyed on a big screen.  It's kinda like wondering why a PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN movie is better on a big screen.  Just look at it, and you know why.Also, even without these elements, I would now say that seeing a Simpsons "episode" in a theatre with a few hundred other fans is a beautiful experience.  That alone was worth the money.  It was a communal event.  One drawback...I must now see the movie again, because we were all laughing so hard at times that I know I missed some stuff!!The movie is funny, touching and inventive.  It's a wonderful effort and I had a GREAT time!!Couple of little things that seem to be of concern to some of the reviewers here.  Remember, the movie is PG-13 and it should be.  Don't take a five year old or ten year old.  Do they fully appreciate the humor of the Simpsons anyway.  But just so you know...Homer gets to flip the bird (VERY funny), Marge let's out a non-TV friendly obscenity and in a jaw-droppingly funny scene, Bart skateboards in the nude and we briefly see a bit more than we expected!!  This scene also brought what is now the funniest Ralph Wiggums line ever (replacing "My cat's breath smells like cat food.")Just writing this review, I want to go see the movie again right now.
summary: For Simpsons fans...it's 90 minutes of pure bliss!!

reviewText: ***1/2With an extended running time of one hour and twenty-six minutes and a wide screen ration of 2:35 instead of the usual 1.33:1, "The Simpsons Movie" is longer and bigger than the average series episode to be sure...but is it funnier?  Well, not quite.  That's a caveat I feel obliged to offer for those expecting this to be the laugh-riot sensation of all time.  It isn't.  Still, compared to most of the big screen comedies that have come our way this season, "The Simpson Movie" is one heck of a funny and entertaining movie - provided you don't go into it expecting more than the movie itself can reasonably deliver.The plotting, which is normally pretty freeform and surrealistic to begin with, has been ratcheted up even further in that direction for the movie.  The story has Homer causing a major environmental catastrophe in the town of Springfield when he thoughtlessly dumps a massive container of pig manure in the local lake, turning it into a sludgy toxic swamp.  To deal with this emerging national threat, President Schwarzenegger has a huge glass dome placed over the city, trapping the understandably irate citizenry inside.  There's no point in revealing anything more about the storyline except to say that it is up to Homer to save the day, which, of course, he does, in his own inimitable way.Fans of the series will be happy to know that "The Simpsons Movie" effortlessly captures the manic energy, sophisticated satire and devil-may-care spirit that have been its hallmarks from the very beginning.  Homer's good-natured bumbling, Marge's exasperated pragmatism, Lisa's unquenchable optimism, and, of course, Bart's fresh-faced mischievousness are all on full display in the movie (along with something else of Bart`s that is very much on display as well).  The other favorites who show up on screen include the perennial toddler, Maggie, Grampa Simpson, Ned Flanders, Mr. Burns, Millhouse, Krusty the Clown and others too numerous to mention.A team of well over a dozen writers - headed by series creators Matt Groening and James L. Brooks - has come up with some hilarious situations and one-liners, enough, in fact, to compensate for the very few ideas or jokes that flame out or misfire.  The zinger-to-dud ratio is one of the best we`ve encountered in quite some time at the movies, though it's not as high, perhaps, as the best work in the series.  As with most feature-length comedies, the concept does feel a little stretched at times and the humor itself runs a trifle thin.  Still, with this much talent plugging away at the movie, it would be impossible for it to miss or disappoint its fans in any major way.  And, of course, there's the instantly familiar and outstanding voice work from regulars Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner, Nancy Cartwright, Yeardley Smith, Harry Shearer and Hank Azaria to get us into the spirit of the enterprise.The animators have chosen not to tamper too much with the look of the film for its big screen presentation.  There may be a bit more elaborate movement in some of the shots, but, for the most part, this is the same uncluttered, two-dimensional Simpsonian world familiar to us from the series.Indeed, the defining philosophy of those who made the film seems to be, "Why mess with a sure thing?," an approach that can be both a strength and a weakness depending on how one looks at it. For unlike the "South Park" movie, which used its jump to the big screen to expand the scope of its vision and carry the series to a new level, "The Simpsons Movie" feels more like an extended version of a single episode, simply blown up to a more impressive size and length.  Thus, those looking for this to be the best and greatest "Simpson" episode ever may find themselves disappointed with what they find here.  Ditto for those who expect it to provide something different from what they've already seen on TV.  However, those who just want a few good laughs at the expense of everyone's favorite lovably dysfunctional adult and his wise guy son will have a rollicking good time at the movie.

reviewText: *I won't explain the plot of the movie, since many people before already have*After nearly 20 years of hilarity, The Simpsons are long overdue for a movie. And, after all these painful years, it happened. Any Simpsons fan, new or old, should find something they love about this movie. For me, it's the fusion of all Simpsons jokes, both old and new. Bart with his ever-funny way of making people insult themselves without realizing it. And most of all, Homer's ofe-like personality yet still a loving father. There are conflicts in the movie, like there always are, but in the end they do get solved after Homer and Bart stop the bomb from exploding on the city. But possibly the best part is that almost every Simpsons character ever shown in the series is present, though I was surprised that Sideshow Bob was never shown. reviewText: Let's get one thing straight from the get go.  The Simpsons is one of the most beloved TV shows in the world.  Let's also get another thing straight, the show has been around for nearly twenty years and has actually caused a divide among fans.  Those who believe the show is still good (or sometimes better than ever) and still has legs; and those who believe the show has been declining in quality for years.  I warn you of two things before you read on.  The first: I am one of the Simpsons fans who believes the show has been declining for years.  I still sit down and watch the show, but in all honesty, the last good season was probably season 10.  The second: Because of my stance, this review is heavily biased.  I love the Simpsons.  I've sat down and watched it since the first episode aired.  But sometimes even fans have to realize when their favorite show churns out something that doesn't live up to the standards of fans.  Perhaps its because I've been with the show since the beginning that it's easier to find fault with the newer episodes.Despite that, this movie will please people from both sides of the specturm.  Whether you think the show is is better than ever or you think it has declined in quality as I have, there's something here for you and it's partly because every writer who has ever been a part of The Simpsons chipped on.The movie begins in Springfield where Green Day is giving a concert at Lake Springfield.  Unfortunately the lake is so polluted that the stage Green Day is singing on (it's floating on the lake) that it eats away at the stage and it sinks taking Green Day with them.  This forces Lisa Simpson to hold a town meeting where she presents her lecture entitled "An Irritating  Truth," (obviously a parody of Al Gore's documentary).  In addition, Homer and Bart have some fun (a moment so hilarious you'll miss out on some of the dialog because you'll be laughing too hard) which eventually lands them in Krusty Burger where Krusty is doing a shoot for a commercial.  When its over he orders the Pig be killed... and Homer can't let that happen.  So instead he saves the pig's life and takes him home.The citizens of Springfield agree to stop dumping trash in the lake.  Of course, there is one man who will dump something in there, of course... Homer Simpson.  When Marge asks him just Homer has been doing with the pig's "leavings" he shows her a silo aptly marked: Pig Crap.  Of course, Marge is disgusted and says that Homer still has to do something about it.  So what does Homer do?  Dumps it in Lake Springfield which causes a series of events that soon reach Washington D.C. and a corrupt politician. In the end, Springfield gets encased in a giant glass dome.  When they wonder why, they eventually find out that Homer is to blame.  Through strange circumstances the family manages to escape Springfield and go to Alaska where they no longer have to worry about Sprigfield's state.  What they find out later, of course, is that the corrupt politician (voiced brilliantly by Albert Brooks) plans to destroy Springfield.  Its up to The Simpsons to save the day.The movie is complete with all the humor you'd expect from the show itself.  Parodies, clever and witty dialog (there are some keepers here), physical abuse of Homer, Bart's shenanigans, Lisa's unpopularity... even the over the top zaniness that some from my side of the spectrum have come to loathe.  And of course, the movie pokes fun on a political and religious scale.  The whole plot of the movie is based around environmentalism and corrupt politicians while they also do their share to make fun of religion.  The Simpsons has never been shy about tackling controversial issues and this movie is no different.  Take some things too seriously and you'll surely be offended.Still, it's actually a very funny movie.  Especially the first twenty minutes.  There wasn't a single person in the theater not laughing at what was happening.  This movie is fun of memorable moments.  The infamous Spider-Pig is but one ingenious example.And then there are some bits of the movie that just fall flat.  This would be the humor that has been coming out within the past couple of seasons.  There are some parts that so over the top in stupidity that you'll either love them or hate them.  Homer's character is also unbalanced.  Homer has always been an oaf but at some moments he is unreasonably stupid.  At others he's not nearly as dumb.  In other words, the mesh of Classic Simpsons vs. Newer Simpsons is all too obvious in many areas.There are some other nit-picky things.  Some stories just aren't complete.  Lisa, for example meets a boy who she falls head over heels with, but the movie never completes this story arc.  Another nit-picky fan gripe is that a lot of the film just isn't in Springfield to begin with.  This means that while you see many of the residents, you don't spend much time.  Most of the Springfield denizens we've come to love (Principal Skinner, Mr. Burns, Chief Wiggum etc.) are on camera for mere seconds and hardly say or do anything.  It's almost like playing "Where's Waldo" only with The Simpsons cast.  It's not too big of a gripe, however.  With so many residents in Springfield you couldn't expect to see them all.  Just the same we don't really explore Springfield to begin with.  We don't go inside the school or the police station or anything.  Most of it is spent either at The Simpson's home or various places you've never seen in the show.But the biggest gripe?  That this is a Simpsons movie where Mr. Burns is not the main villain.  While watching this, I couldn't get over the fact that you only see Mr. Burns twice.  He's one of the most malicious characters in the show.  He's been involved in some of The Simpsons best lived moments, but here he doesn't even use his famous, "Excellent" phrase.  Not that the corrupt politician voiced by Brooks is bad, but it would've been far better had Mr. Burns been the main adversary.The final thing is that the movie is rather short and feels more like an extended episode rather than a full blown movie.  At 87 minutes it goes by in a flash.  And yet, despite which side you fall on: Classic vs. New, you yearn for the movie to be longer because regardless of anything, it's funny.  But it's also because you wish you could see more.It can't be easy to make a movie to a series that's been around for nearly two decades.  Especially with expectations so high.  The Simpsons Movie succeeded by having a successful run at the box office.  However, if you're from my side of the woods: Meaning you love the classic Simpsons episodes a lot... there's something to be desired that isn't there.For what it's worth it IS a good movie.  It's just a movie that had so much potential to be so much better.
summary: A LIttle of the Good Mixed With a Little of the Bad

reviewText: "The Simpsons" is the longest-running TV sitcom ever.  Its network run has surpassed those of "M*A*S*H" (11 seasons), "My Three Sons" (12 seasons), and even "The Adventures of Ozzie & Harriet" (14 seasons).  About to enter its nineteenth season in prime time, this cartoon series shows no signs of old age.With the proliferation of animated films that has come to multiplexes in recent years, it was inevitable that Homer, Marge, Lisa, Bart, Maggie Simpson and their friends and neighbors would find themselves in a feature film.  "The Simpsons Movie" is a very funny continuation of the family's adventures, complete with Homer's buffoonery, Bart's devilishness, Lisa's do-goodedness, and Maggie's virtuosity on the pacifier.Homer brings a pig home for a pet, stores its droppings in a homemade silo in the back yard and then, prompted by Marge to get rid of the leaking eyesore, dumps it into Lake Springfield, causing an environmental emergency so dire that the government steps in with an iron hand and questionable efficiency.  The plot includes a giant dome, an angry mob, and a touchy-feely session with an Inuit with magical powers during a journey to the "country" of Alaska.As in the weekly TV series, the movie has its share of witty barbs directed against governmental expediency, abuse of authority, political correctness, and even Fox's own in-your-face promotion.  But these are blended in with the movie's many gags, visual and verbal.  Sitting in the theatre, laughing vigorously along with the rest of the packed audience, I realized why we love the Simpsons.  The family is not the average American family, as so many sitcoms have tried to represent.  Rather, the Simpsons are a comically dysfunctional family bonded by their love and perseverance to get through the day, no matter what.  This is something we can all identify with.Dan Castellaneta, Julie Kavner, Nancy Cartwright, Yeardley Smith, Harry Shearer, and Hank Azaria provide the familiar voice talent.  Guest voice star Albert Brooks plays officious EPA bigwig Russ Cargill.What makes the film so engaging is the focus on the five family members, rather than sprinkling subplots in a million directions to include every character who's ever appeared on the show. I confess, however, that I did miss the sullen personalities of Marge's sisters, Patty and Selma.  Salary demands?  The story is cohesive, easy to follow, and has its share of suspense as well as hilarious moments.There are a number of self-targeted jokes in the movie.  As the 20th Century-Fox logo looms majestically, little Ralph Wiggum, standing atop the logo, vocally accompanies the fanfare.  Homer turns to the audience shortly into the film and exclaims, "I can't believe anyone would pay for something they can see on TV for free."  Bart writes on the blackboard, "I will not illegally download this movie."  And so it goes.If you recall the 1980 film, "Airplane!," you'll have an idea of the film's structure:  zillions of gags with a basic story line tossed in.  The story is more clearly defined in "The Simpsons Movie," but the final film looks as if huge emphasis was placed on keeping things light and funny.  The writers and director David Silverman have succeeded in making "The Simpsons Movie," joke for joke, one of the funniest films of 2007.Simpsons fans simply must see the movie.  For the rest of us, it's a true romp -- a wickedly clever movie that can be enjoyed on many levels.  It's great fun for kids, who will feel superior to and chuckle at Homer's lamebrained exploits, and adults will appreciate the bits of satire and cultural references.Rated PG-13 for its irreverence, "The Simpsons Movie" offers viewers a comedy roller-coaster ride.  At under ninety minutes, the film leaves us laughing without overstaying its welcome.  A word of advice:  read the end credits.

reviewText: "The Simpsons Movie" is, in a word, hilarious.I had a number of fears when I first heard they were finally bringing the animated television sitcom to the big screen.Frequently, when a half-hour long sitcom does an hour long "special", the longer format is made up of two episodes strung together. Would "The Simpsons Movie" be simply three episodes strung together to masquerade as a feature length film? Thankfully, it isn't. They have taken a larger theme, the pollution of the environment, and give each of the characters an overall piece of this main story while they deal with problems and situations of their own. Most of these are also connected to the environment. This allows them to tie all of the stories together and to give all of our favorite characters a piece of the pie.Would the film reflect the quality of the series currently or actually be funny?The environment? "Well, that sounds awfully "After School Special" you might say. You would be wrong.  One of the things I love about the first, oh say, ten years of the series, is how madcap the series was. Big emphasis on `was'. One moment, the family would be doing one activity, lampooning a handful of different pop culture references, then they would be on to another madcap thing, lampooning a whole different set of pop culture references. Better yet, the story connected these moments Now, the story movies from point A to point B with a couple of jokes thrown in.In "Movie", they use the environment as a framework allowing all of the characters in the family and the entire town of Springfield, to interact and highlight their comic personalities. The story drives the film, allowing the characters to bring their own personalities to the dilemma. This brought back memories of some of my favorite episodes, episodes in which Homer & Marge visit a candy convention and Homer becoming the poster child for sexual perverts everywhere, or Homer deciding he doesn't want to go to church and starting his own religion something God apparently approves of, or Lisa's need for braces driving Homer to become the head of his union and going head to head with Mr. Burns. There are so many classic episodes of "The Simpsons" it would be impossible to list them all. What do these classic episodes have in common? They take no prisoners. One moment, they might be making fun of Hollywood, the next religion, and it all works because they have created a story that can handle wildly divergent ideas. "Movie" follows this formula. Using the environment as an overall theme, they take jabs at religion, celebrity spokespeople, Hollywood, politics and "An Inconvenient Truth"."Movie" is hilarious and has a lot of laughs packed into its 90 minute running time. But it isn't a laugh a minute. There are a couple of moments when the story takes over and the filmmakers try to make Marge and Homer's relationship dramatic. These moments work, but they cut through the comedy like a knife through butter.The filmmakers have taken the familiar landscape of Springfield and our favorite television characters and given them a suitable big screen upgrade. They have maintained the largely 2-D look and feel of the series but have given it a larger depth. Some scenes have striking shadows added to give the film a more artistic look. The family travels to a new state and this area is depicted in a beauty that would not have been possible with the constraints of a television schedule or budget.They have even incorporated the use of CGI. Much like in a Disney film, the animators use CGI to control the crowds or to give the action a little more fluidity in certain scenes. In one scene, the camera tracks through an angry mob and this was done with the aid of CGI. The characters are also given a slightly different appearance. The lines used to draw them appear thicker, giving them a slightly more rounded quality."Movie" tries to incorporate all of the characters at some point or another and this gives the entire great voice cast an opportunity to show off their skills. Because this is a feature length film, the story explores the relationships between certain characters more fully and allows the voice actors to show off why they have helped to make the series so memorable for so many years.The story? The story is really good. But to talk about any of it would be to spoil part of the fun, some of the jokes, some of the surprise. You'll have to see it yourself, to experience all of the fun."The Simpsons Movie" is a great summer movie, with a lot of laughs for both adults and kids. It is sure to convert a large group of viewers into fans and reenergize some die-hard fans who have become disappointed with the series.
summary: Recaptures the Spirit of the Best Years of the Show

reviewText: I have not laughed this hard in a theater in years. Yes, The Simpsons' big screen debut is really that good. While it isn't as mind-boggling as "South Park - Bigger, Longer & Uncut," it kicks off with Homer snidely blowing off all of us in the movie seats and never lets down the momentum. Where the South Park movie took its screen time to move past the 30-minutes of formulaic writing (and was brilliant because of that), "The Simpsons Movie" is basically an extended episode, with Bart flashing the crowd and Marge uttering a curse word.Not that there's anything wrong with that. The plot is basic Simpsons. Homer screws up, Marge doubts their marriage, Lisa finds love, Bart and Homer save the day. But the real revelation is that Ned Flanders becomes a sympathetic character. Bart gets despondent when Homer takes on Spider Pig, and discovers the world of parenting by running to Ned's door. In the past, Ned has been the object of derision, and for the first time he is given an extensive fleshing out. It's probably this film's greatest expansion.Of course, Ned doesn't get the final say. That belongs to Bart and Homer (and in the very funny closing credits - DON'T LEAVE TILL THEY ARE DONE - Maggie), and Homer and Marge. The usual cascade of satire and irreverence flows non-stop and all the characters show up. (I did miss Shawn Colvin's bit as Ned's girlfriend, though.) Pop culture jokes are everywhere, so the gamut of "funny" runs from slapstick that the little ones will laugh at to slightly more risque things for us grown-up types. (Like the evil empire rodent crack, or Homer flipping through a Bible and shouting "This book doesn't have any answers!")I even must admit that I have not watched much of the last few seasons of The Simpsons on TV. But this still made me laugh long and hard. All the Saturday Night Live knock-offs and creepy loser redneck movies have not been consistent enough to hold the laughs (sorry, Larry the Cable Guy and Will Ferrell) at any sustainable level. With so few movies able to make me do that anymore, "The Simpsons Movie" deserves all five of its stars.

reviewText: Given Hollywood's ongoing desire to turn every hit TV show into a movie-- it's hard to believe that it took something as popular as The Simpsons 18 years to make their first leap onto the big screen...And all I can say is: It was worth the wait...The Simpsons Movie finds Homer (voiced by Dan Castellaneta), rescuing a pig from certain death, bringing it home to raise as a house pet--over the objections of Marge (voiced by Julie Kavner). One leaky silo full of pig poop into the town's water supply later - and you have an environmental disaster the likes of which Springfield has never seen. Soon the entire town turns into a vengeful mob, heading straight for the Simpson household. As the family makes a narrow escape, they soon finds themselves divided by conflict.The citizens of Springfield have every reason to be very angry. The events triggered by Homer has drawn the attention of U.S. President Arnold Schwarzenegger (voiced by Harry Shearer) and Environmental Protection Agency chief Russ Cargill (voiced by Albert Brooks). Cargill tells the president that he has a plan to contain the disaster.The "plan" Cargill puts into motion means the end of Springfield...Can Homer save his marriage, repair his fractured family, and rescue the town he calls home from certain doom?The movie is a riot! Written by series creator Matt Groening and executive producer James L. Brooks--along with a gaggle of the show's most talented writers--the screenplay offers us plenty of good old fashioned belly laughs. I think the film does the impossible: It will please not only fans who have been with the show since day one--but also those folks who may have been away for awhile and new fans as well. The main plot of the film works because those responsible didn't mess with the tried and true formula of their past success.Many of the best episodes of the series have Homer screwing up and then having to make good--The film does just that--but with a much bigger canvas. The PG-13 rating also allows for a few more adult oriented gags--seeing Bart (voiced by Nancy Cartwright) buck naked on his skateboard for example. Thank goodness the flick also has plenty of that wicked topical satire that is a staple of the series..Subplots involving Lisa (voiced by Yeardley Smith) finding a boyfriend and neighbor Ned Flanders getting closer to Bart provide a few chuckles. You'll also hear vocal cameos from Billie Joe Armstrong, Tre Cool, Mike Dirnt--Better known as the rock band Green Day--and Oscar winner Tom Hanks...I have to say, I expected there to be a few more star studded cameos given the circumstances though...The film is a winner! It's only fault is that it does drag a bit in the middle but fortunately the pace picks right back up and it's conclusion is worth it. To get the most bang for your movie buck--Be sure to stay right through the end credits for truly funny stuff.I close with one suggestion as the producers move forward--More Mr. Burns and Smithers in the sequel! And Spider-Pig Rules!!

reviewText: Imagining American audiences' responses to "The Simpsons Movie" is like imagining the neanderthal response to fire: it's unbelievable. You can touch it, feel it. You can see it. Your friends can see it, so it's really there. You can experience it any time. You dreamed about it, but you never thought it would be there. The countless fans of "The Simpsons" have been dreaming of a theatrical film for more than a decade, and now, 18 years after the debut of one of television's most beloved series, it makes the leap to the big screen perhaps more gracefully than any TV show has ever done.Part of the appeal of the film is that it feels like you're watching a long episode of "The Simpsons," and yet what you're watching is unmistakably a genuine film. For one thing, the animation's changed; computers were used in part to animate the film. It hasn't changed too much, though; fans may rest. Otherwise, though, everything you love about "The Simpsons" remains intact: all your favorite characters, from Apu to Chief Wiggum, all your favorite places, from Springfield's church to Monty Burns' estate, and all that moronic yet inexplicably brilliant humor.Like the episodes of the series, the plot of "The Simpsons Movie" takes a number of absurd twists and turns, but in its most nonsense-resistant form, it involves Homer Simpsons polluting Springfield's water to the point where the EPA (Environmental Protection Agency) places an indestructible dome over the town, trapping its colorful residents within. It doesn't sound like it could last through a feature-length film, but there's more than enough jokes and similar ridiculousness to keep you laughing well through the film. In fact, very, very few of the jokes fall flat, a worry of those fans who admit that the series' hilarity has been decreasing over the past few years. Truthfully the film may have been funnier had it been released 10 years ago, but as far as a "Simpsons" movie goes, it can't be much better than this.By the way, stick around during the credits.
summary: The 100% genuine "Simpsons" movie - no, you're not dreaming

reviewText: It was a movie that was nearly two-decades in the making.  The creators and writers said they wanted to make sure that when they brought America's favorite prime time animated family to the big screen that it would be done right.  Many past writers were brought back to flesh out the story and enliven the characters.  Most of it was done under a veil of secrecy.  Over 150 different drafts were written and copies of scripts were shredded after each scene was taped.  It was a massive undertaking, but for a show that has grown to include a massive cast of secondary characters it had to be that way.  And for the most part, the efforts to create THE SIMPSONS MOVIE were a success.In THE SIMPSONS MOVIE, Homer almost single handedly destroys Springfield while also threatening the existence of life on the rest of the planet.  Things start off simply enough with a Green Day concert that turns into a disaster.  Then the next day at church Grampa Simpson makes a prophecy of doom that seems to be a message sent by God.  Marge believes the message and tries to decipher the meaning while everyone else thinks Grampa was just rambling like the old man he is.  Lisa finds love with a new boy named Colin who shares the same passions as she does.  Meanwhile, Homer dares Bart to skateboard naked to Krusty Burger and Bart bares his "doodle" for the whole world to see.  It turns out to be the most embarrassing moment of Bart's life.  He starts to view Homer in a negative light and see Ned Flanders as the kind, loving, and caring father that he is.  Later, Homer saves a pig from being slaughtered by Krusty and names him Spider-Pig. Ignored by many, the pig is part of Grampa's prophecy and signals a terrible government sanctioned disaster that forces the Simpsons to become fugitives in Alaska and wipe out all life in Springfield.  Homer finds himself at a major crisis.  He realizes that since he's the cause of all the trouble, he's the only one who can save Springfield and in doing so perhaps restore his relationship with his family.I enjoyed THE SIMPSONS MOVIE. I thought it was both funny and witty.  I especially enjoyed some of the nods and touches to long time fans of the series.  The movie basically feels like a super-extended episode of the show, but with clearer and brighter visuals.  That is perhaps the movie's biggest draw and its biggest flaw at the same time.  Non-fans of the show might become attracted to the show through the film, but die-hard fans of the show might feel disappointed because overall the movie doesn't appear more than an extended regular episode of the show that just looks better.  Of course, that's a problem that any television series attempting to make the leap to the big screen faces.Overall, a slightly disappointing big screen adaptation of THE SIMPSONS television show, but one that is entertaining nonetheless.

reviewText: "The Simpsons" debuted over 20 years ago as short features on the "Tracey Ullman Show."  That's a very long time for fans to wait for a feature length movie, but the movie lived up to my expectations.  Some people are likely to view it as just a long episode; however, releasing it in theaters has allowed "The Simpsons" to push the envelope a bit. Springfield once again courts disaster - this time by having the most polluted lake in the country.  This premise is spun off into various directions that allow for tons of slapstick and sight gags, as well as some pointed comments on environmentalism and politics.  Most of the supporting characters that fans have come to love over the years have at least a few lines, but the Simpson family is front-and-center throughout.The theater I saw the movie in was packed with families, even though it's rated PG-13.  Some of the jokes appealed more to younger kids, such as Homer hammering himself in the eye and the "Spiderpig Song."  Some of the more sophisticated jokes scored with the adults.  Finally, there were enough gags that crossed all lines, particularly a rather risque shot involving Bart skate-boarding that drew gasps.  "The Simpsons Movie" probably isn't appropriate for very young children, what with a couple of sexual jokes, but it's not much worse than what is seen on tv regularly."The Simpsons Movie" is a real winner, which will appeal to many fans.  However, you needn't have been a faithful watcher of the show to enjoy most of the jokes.  I can't wait for it to be released on DVD and add it to the episode collections.

reviewText: After season 7, the jokes of The Simpsons started to get stale and disappear, becoming the dry, preachy animated sitcom it is today. Well, it seems all the jokes that were missing from the contemporary seasons all turned up in the movie.Like most contemporary comedies, The Simpsons Movie is very funny for the first 30 minutes, then tapers off. The first half-hour is non-stop laughter--rather than spread all their ideas out, The Simpsons Movie is non-stop, one after the other, laugh out loud laughs until the brakes are suddenly slammed to a screeching halt. Once the main plot becomes more visible, the jokes die down, it becomes dramatic and definitely too preachy. You are forced to watch the unfunny events of the Simpsons family for the remainder of the flick while having the not-so-subtle political commentary shoved down your throat.The first part of the movie could be compared to early Treehouse of Horror episodes, where zany, non-canon, no-reason humor just comes at you non-stop, and would still be funny after the test of time. The remainder of the movie can be compared to the contemporary Treehouse of Horrors, where the jokes are more based on current events and won't be funny after a few years (the "spiderpig" joke stopped being funny after the first 50 times I saw it in the trailers). They also break the forth wall (commentating that they're in a TV show/movie) which is not funny when done by the Simpsons.Fans of Krusty, Monty Burns, Moe, Apu, and other secondary characters (as they often have the best jokes on the show, after Homer), look elsewhere. The movie focuses primarily on the 5 Simpson family members, and the remainder of the time usually on the new characters created for the movie (such as the unnecessary and unconvincing villain). Sideshow Bob fans, don't even bother.Worth a rental to see the beginning of the movie, once. Worth owning? Not unless you're a die-hard Simpsons fan (who still believes the show is funny even after season 7, when they jumped the shark with the "Who Shot Mr. Burns" cliffhanger).
summary: Funny the first 30 minutes, then dies off
